Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Theory and Practice of Space-Time Variational Integrators for Simulation and Animation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary goal of this research project is to develop novel numerical simulation methods offering a wide range of applications, ranging from the simulation of smoke and fire interacting with moving objects, to the evolution of virus surfaces immersed in fluids.

The approach leverages geometric understanding of the continuous equations of motion developed over the past century, which frames momentum and energy preservation as consequences of basic symmetries and invariance. However, current numerical techniques for simulation rarely capture the geometric principles that have been shown in mathematics and physics to be fundamental to proper dynamical behavior. To develop simulation algorithms that numerically respect both temporal and spatial structures of complex systems, a major part of this research requires the development of a novel framework to combine Lagrangian and Eulerian methods, two common (but rarely combined) representations of motion. Key applications include thin-shell simulation, collision handling, and fluid-structure interaction.

The educational efforts leverage the appeal that graphical simulation demos have to students. The main objective of the educational activities is to motivate students, including underrepresented groups and K-12 students, to train not just in computer science, but also in physics, mathematics, and mechanical engineering to face the increasingly interdisciplinary nature of science.

The resulting computational tools and practical applications (including, e.g., deformation model in biometrics, protein folding and docking, and groundwater simulation) will be disseminated through publications in journals and conferences. Project results can be found at the project website (http://www.cse.msu.edu/~ytong/SpaceTimeIntegrator.html).

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we developed novel simulation methods which preserve defining geometric properties of the continuous equations of motion, including simulation of fluid interacting with moving objects, water drops moving on deforming surfaces, and meshing tools that provide the discretization of the objects and domains involved in such simulations. The geometric properties are directly linked to the symmetries and invariants of motions, such as momentum and energy preservation. Thus they are often crucial to accuracy, robustness, and stability of physical simulations, as well as to the plausibility of simulations that have to run in real-time, such as those on augmented reality devices (HoloLens, Oculus, etc.). Structure preservation of our numerical algorithms is implemented by combining geometric mechanics and discrete differential geometry. We introduced various Eulerian (fixed in space) and Lagrangian (moving with the particles) descriptions of the mechanical system that are advanced in time through a discrete version of the "least action principle".

 

This project resulted in a number of research papers and practical algorithms. Some of these methods provide fast and stable simulations using novel representations to preserve defining geometric properties of the motion. For instance, the variational fluid simulation, which provides a discrete version of Kelvin's theorem, similar to the preservation of angular momentum. We further developed a variational fluid simulation in frequency domain, allowing us to reduce the bulk motion into a number of low frequency fluid motion while preserving Kelvin's theorem. Interaction with deforming surfaces, treatment of surface tension, and even designed fluid motion are also proposed in some of our other simulation methods.

 

In addition to directly applicable simulation methods, we designed novel mathematical tools. For example, we proposed a discrete version of covariant derivative, which is a derivative taken on vector fields, or the more generic tensor fields, on curved surfaces or curved spaces. We also proposed new mathematical definitions for bottlenecks of 3D domains based on a theory called persistent homology, along with an algorithm for their calculation. Such bottleneck locations often have larger impact on simulation results than other regions.

 

Finally, we developed novel tools for creating meshes (a commonly used discretization of geometric shapes) that facilitate the downstream simulation algorithms, including both curved surfaces and irregularly-shaped volumes. For example, we proposed several improvements for automatic generation of hexahedral meshes, which are tiling of domains by cube-like cells and are often ideal for high accuracy physical simulations. We also proposed generators of meshes composed of convex cells that are stretched in directions aligned with the important directions in the simulation (such as material properties or vibration patterns).

 

These novel discretization methods of shapes and motion can be used as typical building blocks or extended by researchers for further enhanced simulation methods.
